awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Managed Groundwater Recharge (MAR) in a year of exceptional precipitation: Evaluating the impact of dry-well versus on-farm recharge on water quality
awd_abstract_narration:
Groundwater is a vital resource that provides drinking water to 2.5 billion people on earth and accounts for about 43% of the water used for irrigation. Many regions have experienced significant depletion in groundwater resources over the last decades. Increased groundwater depletion has motivated the intentional recharge of groundwater aquifers with excess surface water. Intentional groundwater recharge, also called managed aquifer recharge (MAR) has many benefits. It can increase groundwater storage, decrease land subsidence, mitigate flood risk, starve-off sea water intrusion, help regulate streamflow and stream temperature during dry seasons, and improve overall water security. This research will investigate the difference in groundwater quality between two MAR strategies that are used to introduce surface floodwaters into the groundwater system at two side-by-site locations in Central Valley California. Their findings will future implementation of intentional groundwater recharge strategies that improve groundwater quality for communities. 

Following the exceptionally wet year in California that recorded over 300% of its normal precipitation in snowpack and rainfall, resulting in widespread flooding, researchers will study the effect of using the floodwater to recharge aquifers, at two sites undergoing two different MAR strategies, on the quality of groundwater. The MAR strategies are drywells injection and surface flooding of farm fields. The researchers will investigate the occurrence, distribution, and changes in the concentrations of anthropogenic and geogenic contaminants such as nitrate, arsenic, uranium, chromium, other pesticides, and indicators of coliform bacteria. Investigators will quantify the release of contaminants to groundwater from each recharge strategy and assess the links between contaminant mobilization processes to hydrogeochemical conditions that affect the mobilization. The findings from this research will improve understanding of the effect of different managed aquifer recharge strategies and inform the future development of treatment and abatement options during the recharge process for future water management practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF RAPID project investigated the occurrence and concentration changes of anthropogenic chemicals, geogenic contaminants, and microbial pathogens across space and time within two Managed Aquifer Recharge (MAR) systems in California's Central Valley. The study leveraged the unique opportunity of a particularly wet year in 2023 to compare intentional groundwater recharge with flood water in two MAR systems (on-farm recharge [Ag-MAR] and drywells) at a site that shares similar environmental characteristics, making them ideal for comparative analysis of MAR system impacts on water quality.

The primary objective of this project was to assess the fate and transport of contaminants including nitrogen species, pesticides, arsenic, uranium, etc.) within these systems under MAR-induced conditions (e.g., redox potential, pH) to understand contaminant mobilization processes. Extensive sample collection was conducted spanning several months and covering different water sources, including canal water, pore water in the flooded agricultural field and drywell recharge zones, and groundwater monitoring wells. A limitation arose when biological pathogen analysis was not possible due to equipment delays.

Samples underwent detailed analysis for nitrogen species using a discrete analyzer and (oxyhydr)oxides using an ICP mass spectrometer. For trace contaminants, such as pesticides and emerging compounds, samples were processed via mass spectrometry, which detected nine trace organic compounds including DEET, simazine, metolachlor, chlorantraniliprole, and thiamethoxam in pore water samples. The nutrient analysis of water samples from Profiles 1, 2, and 5 at the Ag-MAR site showed initial low nitrogen levels due to leaching, followed by increases in NOx concentrations after water application ceased. Profile 5 exhibited the highest NOx levels, suggesting strong mineralization of organic nitrogen sources during drainage. Groundwater NOx levels were moderate, with one well displaying a clear decline during flooding. Oxyanion and heavy metal analyses across Ag-MAR profiles, canal water, and drywell samples reveal variable contaminant concentrations. Aluminum and manganese levels were highest in drywell samples, and lowest in the canal source water. Profiles in the Ag-MAR site generally had higher arsenic and uranium levels at deeper depths (1.75-2.5 m) suggesting possible mobilization due to recharge. 

Using the HYDRUS 2D software, the team explored simulating changes in subsurface redox and oxygen conditions as a function of microbial activity, by incorporating an empirical equation that simulates soil respiration as a function of microbial carbon and dissolved organic carbon. The model, which was developed for one of the drywells, showed that extended water residence times in deeper soil layers encouraged the loss of oxygen and reduced conditions that promoted the mobilization of arsenic. The team is still in the process of developing the model further to test different controls on redox processes and associated contaminant mobilization.

Overall, the collected data, data analysis and numerical modeling indicate that carefully managing MAR cycles—adjusting wetting and drying cycles—might help control redox conditions and thus limit contaminant mobilization. When water is removed from the soil, it affects the supply of oxygen, thereby changing the redox potential. In deep vadose zones, due to low and slow drainage, oxygen diffusion is limited, and an anaerobic environment is easily formed. This environment significantly affects microbial activities and the type of redox reactions. Periodic drainage events may temporarily introduce oxygen, thereby altering microbial community structure and major redox processes, particularly, in layers characterized by high arsenic concentrations. The modeling results suggest that it is possible to control water residence time and saturation level, thus potentially avoiding redox conditions during MAR operations that would cause geogenic contamination from arsenic. More work is needed to better understand how residence times, water content and microbial oxygen consumption interact to determine redox potential; once these interdependencies become clearer, we should be able to engineer recharge operations with appropriate injection/draining cycles to control redox conditions and, consequently, reduce geogenic contamination of water in the vadose zone.


 

 


Last Modified: 10/17/2024
Modified by: Helen Dahlke
